Boxing was banned in England at the time, and yet the fight was well-attended by people of many classes.
ANB.
ODNB.

Mademoiselle Csillag was an opera singer hailing from Hungary. She played the leading role of Leonora in the 1860 performance of Beethoven's Fidelio in London.
"Royal Italian Opera," Musical World vol. 36 no. 16 (21 April 1860), 256.
"Mdlle. Rosa Csillag," Illustrated London News 1032 (26 May 1860): 509.

Flora Finching is a secondary character in Charles Dickens's novel, Little Dorrit. She is the ex-fiancée of one of the main characters, Arthur Clenham. Her character is depicted as being past her prime and always dwelling in the past (particularly in regards to her broken engagement).
Tom Henshall was the brother of Dinah's childhood friend, Penelope Henshall from Newcastle. In 1860 he was living in Australia and was ostracized from his English family.

Mr. Pigott was an English journalist and literary critic. He worked for The Leader and The Daily News and was also the Examiner of Plays for the Lord Chamberlain's Office from 1874 until his death in 1895. He was close friends with George Eliot and George Henry Lewes, and also knew Dinah's friends Holman Hunt and Margaret Oliphant.
"Edward Smyth Pigott Papers: Finding Aid," Manuscripts Department, mssPIG 1-446, Huntington Library, San Marino California, OAC, accessed 29 June 2017.
John Russell Stephens, "The Censors," The Censorship of English Drama 1824-1901 (New York: Cambridge UP, 1980), 32-35.

Henry Fielding was an eighteenth-century author and playwright. He is widely credited as one of the first English novelists and is famous for his satirical picaresque novels such as Joseph Andrews and Tom Jones.
ODNB.
Jessie Lyon was sister to Hugh Lyon. Jessie, Hugh, and their mother were friends with Dinah through Maggie Paton (Joseph Noel Paton's wife). They were also relations of Lyon Playfair.

Playfair Lyon was a well-known organic chemist and Scottish politician. He often served in advisory roles for British public works, and from 1848 onwards, was a close advisor and assistant to Prince Albert. In 1892 he became the first Baron Playfield of St. Andrews.
ODNB.

Helen Ann Scott was the daughter of the homeopathic doctore, Geddes Mackenzie Scott. She and her family lived in London at Haverstock Hill in the 1860s. She seems to have helped run a Reformatory in London alongside Minna Lovell.
"Obituary: Brodie Helen Ann," Medical Times and Gazette (14 May 1881): 557.
"SCOTT, Geddes Mackenzie," London Medical Biography (Mr. Churchill, 1859): 225.

Bethia Scott was the wife of the homeopathic doctor, Geddes Mackenzie Scott. They lived at 37 Park Road Haverstock Hill in the 1860s before moving to Willesden.
"Marriages," Belfast Newsletter (30 Aug 1831): n. pag.
"Obituary: G.M. Scott, M.A., M.D.," Monthly Homoeopathic Review (2 May 1887): 319.

Dr. Geddes Mackenzie Scott was a Scottish homeopathic doctor. He lived at 37 Park Road Haverstock Hill in the 1860s before moving to Willesden. Dr. Scott also published on public education reform.
"Obituary: G.M. Scott, M.A., M.D.," Monthly Homoeopathic Review (2 May 1887): 319.
Quarterly Review (November 1829): 57.

Alfred Ainger published "Books and their uses" in Macmillan's Magazine in 1859, and in 1887 he was named Canon of Bristol. In 1896 he was appointed chaplain-in-ordinary to Queen Victoria.
ODNB.
Mrs. Ainger was the wife of the Canon Ainger. They were both acquaintances of Dinah's.
Mr. Nicholay was an acquaintance of Ben's in Brazil. He also seems to have been a connection of Dinah's friend Fanny Martin.
Marion Craik was the younger sister of George Lillie Craik. She was Dinah's husband's aunt.

Ary Scheffer was a Romantic painter who specialized in classical literary scenes and portraits.
Encyclopaedia Britannica (1911).
Lily Mott was the first child of Dinah and Ben's friends Albert Mott and Clara Mott (née Dobell).
Emily Jolly was the younger sister of Ellen (Dobell) Jolly's husband, William Jolly.

Superintendent-General William Thomas Doyne was a railway engineer and Consulting Engineer to the Government of Western Australia. He was also Ben Mulock's superior officer during his time with the Army Works Corps in the Crimea.
ADNB.

Maggie Macmillan was the third child of Alexander and Caroline Macmillan.
ODNB.

George Henry Lewes was a writer, lecturer, and literary critic. He wrote multiple articles and reviews on a variety of Victorian authors and part of a company of amateur actors with Charles Dickens in 1847. He was best-known for his long-term affair with Marian Evans, who was better known by her pen-name George Eliot.
ODNB.

Marian Evans worked as a translator, journalist, literary critic, and writer, often under her pseudonym, George Eliot. She was also the anonymous editor of John Chapman's Westminster Review. Her first full length novel was Adam Bede, published in 1859. She needed the protection of a pseudonym due to her infamy as a reviewer and critic in the Westminster Review, her well-known affairs with Lewes and others.
ODNB.

John Chapman published Marian Evan's initial German translations, and ran The Westminster Review. He was also known for his advocation of medical reform and his feminist leanings.
ODNB.

George MacDonald was a writer who was best known for fairy tales, literary parables, and a fierce pride in his Scottish heritage.
ODNB.

Annie Isabella Ritchie née Thackeray was the eldest surviving daughter of William Makepeace Thackeray. She was a well-known English novelist in the mid-Victorian era.
ODNB.

Henry Shorthouse was an English writer who was best known for his instantly successful novel John Inglesant.
ODNB.

Sarah Scott was the wife of Henry Shorthouse. They married in 1857.
ODNB.

Caroline was queen of the U.K. and Ireland from January 1820 to August 1821. She was known for her dramatic behaviour and personal life, and her refusal to be badly treated by her husband, George IV.
ODNB.

Maurice Macmillan was the second son of Daniel and Frances Macmillan. After his father's death in 1857, he was raised by his uncle and aunt Alexander and Caroline Macmillan. He was a classics master at St. Paul's School before joining Macmillan & Co. in 1883. Maurice was married to Nellie Hill at Dinah and George's house in November 1884.
Sevenoaks Chronicle and Kentish Advertiser, 28 November 1884, BNA.
ODNB.

George Macmillan was Alexander and Caroline Macmillan's second son. He entered the firm in 1874.
ODNB.

James MacLehose was a Scottish bookseller and was appointed official printer bookseller for the University of Glasgow in 1871. He published books focusing on theology, European literature, and the ancient world.
ODNB.

Thomas Henry Huxley was a scientific lecturer and biological researcher, known for his work in biological science and evolution. He also wrote a scientific column for the Westminster Review.
ODNB.

Baron Christian Karl Bernhard von Tauchnitz was a publisher with and heir to Tauchnitz, which he joined under his father's guidance in 1866.
Thomas Hardy, "Biographical Index," The Life and Work of Thomas Hardy , ed. Michael Millgate (London: Macmillan, 1984), 150; 597.
Rudolph Schmidt ed., "Tauchnitz, Bernhard," Deutsche Buchhändler. Deutsche Buchdrucker [German Book Dealers and German Book Printers] vol. 5 (Berlin: Eberswalder, 1908), 940–944, http://www.zeno.org/nid/20011438487.

Christian Bernhard, Freiherr von Tauchnitz founded the publishing firm Tauchnitz in 1837. In 1860, he was given the title of Freiherr (Baron) for his services to literature.
Christopher Irmscher, Public Poet, Private Man: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow at 200 (Boston: U Massachussets P, 2009), 162–163.
Rudolph Schmidt ed., "Tauchnitz, Bernhard," Deutsche Buchhändler. Deutsche Buchdrucker [German Book Dealers and German Book Printers] vol. 5 (Berlin: Eberswalder, 1908), 940–944, http://www.zeno.org/nid/20011438487.

Francis Palgrave Turner was a member of the education ministry as well as a Professor of Poetry at Oxford. He was well known for both his art criticisms and an undying devotion to Lord Tennyson.
ODNB.

Mary Adamson Anderson was a member of the Edinburgh Seven, a group of women who submitted an 1870 petition for admission to The Edinburgh Royal Infirmary. She passed her MD examination in 1879, and was senior physician at New Hospital.
ODNB.

Sir Hubert von Herkomer's illustrations were featured in popular periodicals such as Good Words, and his paintings were often displayed in the Royal Academy. He also wrote a number of books, and was the Slade professor of Art at Oxford from 1885 to 1894.
ODNB.

Sir George Grove was a civil engineer as well as a writer on music and a lexicographer. He edited a two-volume dictionary of music for Macmillan, and raised funds for the Royal College of Music.
ODNB.

William Black was a writer who was best-known for his journal contributions. He also wrote novels, the best-known of which are A Daughter of Heth in 1871 and A Princess of Thule in 1874.
ODNB.

Baron Kelvin William Thomson was a mathematician, physicist, and natural philosopher. He was elevated to peerage as Baron Kelvin of Largs, in 1842, the first scientist to do so.
ODNB.

William Aldis Wright made his scholarly name with his contributions to the Dictionary of the Bible. He was the Librarian of Trinity College, Cambridge, edited the Cambridge Shakespeare, and was once known as one of the greatest Shakespearian scholars in Britain.
ODNB.

Sir Arthur Seymour Sullivan was a talented composer, writing symphonies, hymns, and ballads. He was best-known for writing operettas with W.S. Gilbert.
ODNB.

Sir Charles Santley was a singer whose most notable role was Valentine in the English premiere of Faust in 1863. He was the first singer ever to be knighted. He published two books on singing and one memoir.
ODNB.

Bartholomew Price was a tutor and lecturer of Mathematics at Pembroke College, Oxford.
ODNB.
Amy Price was a friend of Dinah's, and the wife of Bartholomew Price.
Mabel Price was the daughter of Amy and Bartholomew Price.

Mary Louisa Molesworth was a novelist and children's writer, who wrote over 100 books. Her best known titles were Carrots in 1876 and The Cuckoo Clock in 1877.
ODNB.

Sir John Frederick Maurice was an army officer and military writer, as well as a Professor of Military Art and History at Staff College, Camberley.
ODNB.

Edward Caird was Professor of Moral Philosophy at the University of Glasgow, and master of Balliol College, Oxford.
ODNB.

Sir Thomas Lauder Brunton was a physician and pharmacologist. He lectured at Middlesex Hospital and St. Bartholomew's Hospital, and wrote The Textbook of Pharmacology in 1885.
ODNB.

Sir Edmund Thomas Bewley was a lawyer and genealogist, and Professor of Feudal and English Law at the University of Dublin. He was Dinah's relative, and wrote a family history book called The Family of Mulock.
ODNB.

William Benham was Divinity tutor and lecturer in English Literature at St. Mark's, Chelsea until 1858. He lectured on Church History and Charles Dickens at the Church Institute in Cantebury.
ODNB.

Matthew Arnold was a poet and a Professor of Poetry at Oxford, as well as a literary, social, and religious critic. He had a reputation as a literary and social controversialist.
ODNB.

Henry Allon was a clergyman with a large and distinguished congregation, and wrote and reviewed for multiple literary journals. He also edited The British Quarterly Review.
ODNB.

Cecil Frances Alexander was a hymn writer and poet who was prominent in the Church of Ireland Hymnal. In 1896 a posthumous collection Poems by Cecil Frances Alexander was published.
ODNB.

George Augustus Henry Sala edited Temple Bar and Cornhill Magazine.
ODNB.

Emily Beesley was the president of the women's liberal association of Paddington, wrote new lyrics for The Wearing of the Green, and wrote Stories from the History of Rome for her four sons.
ODNB.

Sir Leslie Stephen was appointed editor of Cornhill Magazine in 1871. He was also the first editor of the Dictionary of National Biography.
ODNB.

Alfred Smith Barnes founded A.S. Barnes & Co., which primarily published text books. He managed the company until his retirement in 1880.
ODNB.

Francis Joseph Campbell was head and originator of the Royal Normal College for the Blind in London, which still exists today as Royal National College for the Blind. He had a talent for teaching music. He was also an anti-slavery campaigner, and the first blind person to climb Mount Blanc.
Dinah Mulock "Light in Darkness" 1882.

Juliana Horatia Ewing née Gatty was a celebrated children's author, well-known for her folktales and moral stories. She edited and contributed to Aunt Judy's Magazine from 1873 to 1875. She spent two years in Fredricton, New Brunswick when her military husband was posted to Canada.
ODNB.

Horatia Katharine Frances Eden née Gatty was the editor of Aunt Judy's Magazine, which she took over from her mother Margaret Gatty following her death in 1873. She assumed sole control when her sister Juliana Ewing stepped down in 1875. She also published a memorial of her sister's life and works.
ODNB.

Alfred Austin was a poet and a frequent contributor to Macmillan's Magazine. He was the husband of Hester Jane Austin.
ODNB.
Mr. Williams appears to have been an employee of Tauchnitz in 1881.
Mr. Foster appears to have been an employee of Macmillans in 1886.

William Hogarth was a painter and engraver whose prints and "modern moral subjects" often commented on the state of the nation.
ODNB.
Felix W. was an ex-colleague of Dinah and Ben's acquaintance George Springfield. He seems to have taken advantage of Springfield and consequently, Dinah considered him a crook.
Maria Bravender was a friend of the Dobells. She seems to have also known Dinah and Ben.
Mrs. Orrinsmith was the mother of the engraver Harvey Orrinsmith.

Anna was the second daughter of Solomon Levi Behrens. The Behrens were German-Jewish immigrants who were well-known for their contributions to the Jewish community of Manchester. They were also friends with Elizabeth Gaskell and her family.
Irene Wiltshire, ed., "Margaret Emily Gaskell," Letters of Mrs. Gaskell's Daughters, 1856–1914 (Humanities-Ebooks LLP, 2011), 155, n.1.; 156, n.1.
John Martin was the cousin of Dinah's servant Bessy.

Izaak Walton was an English writer and biographer hailing from Staffordshire. He was famous for his best-selling fishing manual, The Compleat Angler, which has been reprinted almost as many times as The Pilgrim's Progress.
ODNB.
John Hyde seems to have been an old family friend of the Mulocks.

Harriet was the younger sister of the publisher Henry Blackett and the middle child of the Blackett family. She lived with her brother and his family for some time when she was suffering from unspecified mental health issues.

Curtiss was Fanny Martin's youngest brother. He was the youngest in a family of five children. In his adulthood, Curtiss was a well-paid surgeon and seems to have travelled frequently. He died before his fiftieth birthday when he was living and working abroad in India.
Hannah Martin was Fanny Martin's younger sister – the fourth of five children in the Martin family. She lived with her mother Matilda Martin until her marriage to Joseph Russell in 1862.
Matilda Martin was Fanny Martin's mother. Her husband Edward Curtiss Martin (a Professor of Music) died in 1853, leaving her to struggle financially.

William Ellery Channing was a well-known and influential Unitarian preacher who was active in the early-nineteenth century.
ANB.
Mrs. Ross stayed at Moor Park in 1857 at the same time as Dinah. John Thom was her brother.

John Thom was a visitor at Moor Park in the mid-1850s and beyond. Prior to his first stay at Moor Park in June 1854, he worked as an English tutor for Henry and Isabella Robinson's sons.
Kate Summerscale, "My Imagination Heated As Though With Realities," Mrs. Robinson's Disgrace: The Private Diary of a Victorian Lady (London: Bloomsbury, 2012), 55–87.
Mr. Warner stayed at Moor Park in 1857 at the same time as Dinah.
Mrs. Hornidge stayed at Moor Park in 1857 at the same time as Dinah. She was a widowed woman living in London.
Sarah Wayte was Mrs. Hornidge's general servant in 1857. Dinah was acquainted with her cousin from Newcastle-under-Lyne.
Wayte was an ironmonger based out of Newcastle-under-Lyne. Dinah knew of him because he sold kitchenware to her family when they lived in Newcastle in the 1830s.
Mary Pike was the mother of Dinah's young friends Connie, Ada, and Bel Pike. She was born in Stoke-upon-Trent the year after after Dinah.
Mary Paterson was mother to Helen Allingham and sister to Laura Herford.

Helena Saville Faucit (later Lady Martin) was a popular English actress. She and her husband Sir Theodore Martin were friends of the Royal Family.
ODNB.

Sir Theodore Martin was a Scottish lawyer but was better-known as an author of biographies. He was knighted in 1880 after publishing a very thorough biography of Prince Albert.
ODNB.

Nellie Hill was an acquaintance of Dinah's – a widow who lived in Shortlands. She was married to Maurice Macmillan at the Corner House in November 1884, and was given away by James Russell Lowell.
Sevenoaks Chronicle and Kentish Advertiser (28 November 1884), Sevenoaks, Kent, BNA.
ODNB.
David Copperfield is the titular character of Charles Dickens's eighth novel.
Dora Spenlow is the love interest, first wife, and then widow of David Copperfield in the novel David Copperfield by Charles Dickens
The orphaned Eleanor Ogilvie is a primary character in Dinah's 1849 novel The Ogilvies.
Katharine Ogilvie is a primary character in Dinah's 1849 novel The Ogilvies.
Philip Wychnor is a primary character in Dinah's 1849 novel The Ogilvies. He is the love interest of Eleanor Ogilvie.
Leigh Pennythorne is a secondary character in Dinah's 1849 novel, The Ogilvies.
King Lear is the titular character in a Shakespearean play.
Ned Locksley is a fictional character in Mr. Chermside's novel, Ned Locksley.
Herbert Mansfield is a fictional character from The Moor Cottage by Miss Blyth.
Mabel is a fictional character from The Moor Cottage by Miss Blyth.
Millicent is a fictional character from The Moor Cottage by Miss Blyth.
Captain Jackson is a fictional character from The Moor Cottage by Miss Blyth.
Lady S. is a fictional character in Ned Locksley by Mr. Chermside.

Elisabetta was the titular character in The Story of Elisabetta Sirani – a short story that Dinah translated from Italian in 1845. The real Elisabetta Sirani was a successful Italian Baroque painter who died unexpectedly at the age of 27 in 1665. It is believed that she was poisoned by a jealous handmaiden.

Battista Zani was a central character in The Story of Elisabetta Sirani – a short story that Dinah translated from Italian in 1845. The real Battista Zani was an amateur painter who courted Elisabetta Sirani.
Mr. Pecksniff is a character in Dicken's novel Martin Chuzzlewit.
Tyrell is a villainous character in Colin Hazelwood's melodramatic stage adaptation of A Life For A Life in 1860.
Burgs is the second villainous character added to the narrative for Colin Hazelwood's melodramatic stage adaptation of A Life For A Life in 1860.
Dora is the main female protagonist in A Life For a Life. She also appears in the 1860 stage adaptation.
Dr. Max Urquhart is the main male protagonist and love interest in A Life For a Life. He also appears in the 1860 stage adaptation.
Harry is Dora's half-brother in A Life For A Life. He also appears in the 1860 stage adaptation.
Jarvis served with Ben in the Crimea.
Harriet Parr was an acquaintance of Dinah's. She was also a novelist and published under a pseudonym Holme Lee in addition to her own name.
Arlice seems to have been one of Dinah's servants at Wildwood.
Betty was one of the three young girls to whom Dinah dedicated "How to Win Love, or Rhoda's Lesson."
Frances was one of the three young girls to whom Dinah dedicated "How to Win Love, or Rhoda's Lesson."
Jeannie was one of the three young girls to whom Dinah dedicated "How to Win Love, or Rhoda's Lesson."

David Laing was a Scottish writer, editor, and bookseller.
Chambers's Cyclopaedia of English Literature from 1830 to 1882, fourth ed., ed. Robert Carruthers, LL. D. (Edinburgh: W. & R. Chambers, 1894) 785, Web.
Willie was likely one of Dinah's servants at Wildwood.
Mrs. Linos appears to be a music instructor who helped with Dinah Craik's glee club c. 1862.
This name is noted by an unknown hand on letter PU34 in the Princeton Parrish Collection. Miss Meugius is said to be a friend of Miss Marchall's and an aspiring translator.
Dinah had a letter from Mrs. Mulock around August 1887 in which she mentions her son Francis is dead.
Kate and her sister Lily are cousins of the Pike sisters.
Lily and her sister Kate are cousins of the Pike sisters.
In one of Dinah's letters, she mentions Mrs. Homfray will give them an address to stay in Rome.
Ida was a friend of the Craiks.
Emma seems to have been a servant of Dinah's.
Miguel de Cervantes was a seventeenth-century Spanish writer.
Referred to as Aunt Eunice
Miss McDounell owned a horse that Dinah once planned to borrow.
Maggie Hooper lived in Shortlands, Kent.
Jessie was a young servant of the Craiks in the 1880s in the Corner House.
Katie was a servant of the Craiks in the 1880s.
Mrs. Dybeen was the housekeeper at Dinah Craik's cottage in Dover.
Richard Horner was Dinah's great-uncle. He was the brother of Dinah's grandmother, Maria (Horner) Mulock.
According to Dinah's aunt Alicia, Harriet Mulock was the sister of Dinah's paternal grandfather, Robert Mulock.
Horace Dobell was a brother of Sydney and Clarence Dobell.
Elizabeth Mary Dobell was married to Horace Dobell. She was also the younger sister of Sydney Dobell's wife, Emily.
Eveline Dobell was the youngest child and only daughter of Clarence and Emily Dobell.
Mrs. Mulock was the mother of Francis Mulock.
Eliza was one of Dinah's servants.
Lady Tennyson was married to Alfred Lord Tennyson.
Sarah was the cook for the Macmillan's.
Mrs. Brown was an acquaintance of the Mulock family. She lived in London. It seems that she helped to care for Thomas Mulock Jr.'s horse, Nell, while he was at away at sea.
William Lee was married to Dinah's cousin Elizabeth (Lizzie) Reade.
Muriel Lee was the daughter of William and Elizabeth Lee.
Henrietta Keddie was a Scottish novelist and a friend of Dinah's. She also adopted a daughter.
Clara was an elder sister of Dinah's friend Clarence Dobell. In 1852, she married Ben's friend Albert Mott.
Eliza Mott was the mother of Ben's good friend Albert Mott.

persName.note:
Emma Parker was Dinah's maternal aunt. She, her husband William Parker, and their family lived at Lysways Hall near Lichfield.
Reade, The Mellards & Their Descendants, 18-20.

person.note:
Captain Hugh Montgomery was Mary Montgomery's brother. He was also a friend of Lady Byron's.
Judith Baillie Slaigle, ed., "To Mary Montgomery," Collected Letters of Joanna Baillie, vol. 2 (London: Associated UP, 1999), 846.
Ben Mulock worked closely with John Watson in Brazil. Watson was the contractor for the developing Brazilian railway.
Mrs. Watson was married to John Watson, the contractor for the railway line Ben worked for in Brazil.

Signor Barbera also operated as an arbiter between the publishing firm Le Monnier and Italian author Manzoni over a copyright conflict in 1864.
The Literary World, James Clarke & Company, 1883.
Bessy was one of Dinah's maids at Lynover Cottage.
Miss Broadribb was John Miers's governess ca. 1860.
Aleck Fry was Susan Mary (Fry) Miers's brother and Frank Miers's brother-in-law.

Mrs. Siddons was a famous eighteenth-century Welsh actress who specialized in tragedy.
ODNB.
Charlotte Buss stayed with Marian James at Lynover Cottage while Dinah was at Moor Park in c. 1856. She might have been a friend of theirs or a subletter.

org.note:
Edward Bentley, his son Richard and his grand-son George were three generations of publishers based out of London. The name Bentley is best-known for Richard Bentley's periodical "Bentley's Miscellany" which was edited by Charles Dickens.
Anderson, Patricia J. and Jonathan Rose, eds., "Richard Bentley," British Literary Publishing Houses, 1820-1880 106, (Detroit: Gale, 1991), 39-52. DLB 106.

Wm. S. Orr & Co was a London-based publisher run by William Somerville Orr.
ODNB.

T.C. Newby was a London publishing company run by Thomas Cautley Newby.
ODNB.
Chambers was a publishing company located in Edinburgh.
Cadell & Co was a Scottish publishing company located in Edinburgh.
Daldy Isbister & Co was a publishing company located in London.

Arthus Hall, Virtue & Co was an English publishing company founded c. 1848.
Boase, G. C., "Virtue James Sprent (1829-1892)," ODNB.
Hodgson & Graves was an English publishing company located at 6 Pall Mall, London.

John W. Parker & Son (and all its iterations) was a publishing company located in central London. From 1848, when the firm was under the direction of the younger Parker, the firm became known for embracing liberal and eventually socialist Christianity.
ODNB.

George Bell, Bell and Daldy, and George Bell and Sons were all London publishing companies owned or partially owned by George Bell.
ODNB.
Williams & Norgate were publishers with offices in London and Edinburgh. They specialized in scientific literature.
Sampson Low, Son and Company was a publishing office originally located on Fleet Street. It was founded by the well-known bookseller Sampson Low and his eldest son in 1848. ODNB.
Phillips, Sampson and Co. was a publishing firm based out of Boston. They were the founders and original publishers of the Atlantic Monthly.

Oliphant, Anderson, & Ferrier was a Scottish publishing company that was most active in the mid-late nineteenth century. They specialized in domestic fiction and biographies.
"Messrs Oliphant, Anderson & Ferrier." Publishers' Circular and Booksllers' Record of British and Foreign Literature vol. 54, no. 1304 (27 June 1891): 680-682. Web.

Griffin & Co was a Glasgow-based publishing business of Richard Griffin, John Joseph Griffin and Charles Griffin. The company sold an ecletic combination of chemicals and books.
ODNB.

Oliver & Boyds was a Scottish publishing company based in Edinburgh. They specialized in non-fiction, educational, and medical publications.
David Finkelstein and Alistair McCleery, eds., Edinburgh History of the Book in Scotland vol. 4 (Edinburgh UP, 2007), 348.
The Mulocks were Dinah's immediate paternal family.

The Macmillans were the family members of Daniel and Alexander Macmillan, founders of the Macmillan publishing house. For a list of the brothers' respective spouses and children, consult the ODNB entry "Macmillan Family."
The Craiks were Dinah's husband George's family.
The Singletons were friends of Dinah's while she lived at Hampstead Heath.
Dinah was very close with the Marston family throughout the 1850s and beyond. She was godmother to the family's youngest child, Philip Bourke Marston.
Dinah's paternal aunts Jane, Emily, Eliza, Frances, Ann, and Eliza Mulock lived at Bath.
The Chambers Family refers to Scottish publishers William & Robert Chambers, their wives, and their children.
The Parkers were the family of Dinah's maternal aunt Emma Parker and her husband William.
The De Morgan Family includes Professor Augustus De Morgan, the spiritualist writer and social activist Sophia De Morgan, and their seven children.
The Tomlinsons were family friends of the Mulocks.
The Jameses were the family of Dinah's close friend, Marian James.
The Ogilvies were a family that Ben and Dinah knew in Brazil.
The Meadows family consisted of Kenny and Agnes Meadows and their children.
The Halls were the family of Samuel Carter and Anna Maria Hall. They had no children.

The Leweses were the family of the philosopher and literary critic, George Henry Lewes. This includes his legal wife Agnes Lewes, with whom he had an open relationship, and his co-habitating partner Mary Ann Evans (pseud. George Eliot). He and Agnes had three children together and she had another four with Thornton Hunt. With the exception of Hunt, all of these people lived together as the Leweses.
ODNB.
The Sharpes were the family of one of Dinah's early publishers, Thomas Bowdler Sharpe (of Sharpe's London Magazine).
The Marches were friends of Thomas Mulock's. They lived in Cresswell, Staffordshire. They were dissenting pre-Adamites.
The Jacksons seem to have been friends of the Dobells and acquaintances (if not friends) of Dinah's.
The Richardsons seem to have been friends of the Dobells and acquaintances (if not friends) of Dinah's.
The Alisons were friends of Dinah's when she lived at Wildwood. They were also friends with the Ziepels and the Burnses. They likely lived near Hampstead.
The Burnses were friends of Dinah's when she lived at Wildwood. They were also friends with the Ziepels and the Alisons. They likely lived near Hampstead.
The Lanes were the family of Dr. Edward Lane and his wife Mary (née Drysdale) Lane. The Lanes owned hydrotherapy establishments in the nineteenth century, including the famous Moor Park.
Taylor was the family name of Dinah's acquaintances, Mary and Peter Taylor.
The Motts were the family members of Dinah and Ben's friends Albert and Clara (Dobell) Mott.
The Bowers were acquaintances of Dinah's who lived at New Brighton.
The Lintons were the family of W.J. Linton.

Mudie's Circulating Library was a popular subscription-based lending library that operated in London from 1842 to 1894. Mudie's dealt exclusively in three-volume novels whose subject matters would appeal to middle-class families.
George P. Landow, "Mudie's Select Library and the Form of Victorian Fiction," Victorian Web, last modified 2001, accessed 28 June 2017.

The Stationers' Company was a Guild of Stationers in the city of London. At its conception, the Guild was comprised of those who worked in the trade of manuscript books (i.e. copiers, limners, and booksellers) but came to include printers in the early sixteenth century. The Stationers' Company owned a building in London called Stationers' Hall.
"The Hall & Heritage," The Stationers' Company, accessed Aug. 3, 2015. https://stationers.org/the-hall-heritage.html.

Ben Rhydding was a medical centre near Leeds known for its physicians' expertise in Hydro-Therapeutics. Dinah sent her brother Ben to Ben Rhydding after he had a "nervous dyspeptic attack".
"Ben Rhydding," Medical Times and Gazette Advertiser 3, no. 1124 (June 22, 1872): 181 and 246.

org.orgName: Catharine Lodge School for Young Ladies
org.note: Established in 1851, the Catharine Lodge School for Young Ladies was a boarding and day school that prepared middle-class girls to be good governesses and wives.

Established in 1264, Merton College was one of the first constituent colleges of the University of Oxford.
"The history of Merton," Merton College: Oxford, accessed July 14, 2015, http://www.merton.ox.ac.uk/about/history-merton.

Established in 1852, The Saltley Reformatory was a boy's industrial school located in central Birmingham. Its goal was to train juvenile offenders in the trades so as to mould them into productive members of society and prevent them from falling into a life of crime.
ODNB.
Barnett, Mary G. "D— The First Reformatory School Acts," Young Delinquents: A Study of Reformatory and Industrial Schools, (New York, E. P. Dutton & Co., 1913): 20-22.

Rescue Society's Reformatory for Girls was located at 28 Church Road in Hampstead until it opted to resign its certificate in June 1860. A new girl's reformatory immediately opened down the road at 28 Church Road, called the Hampstead Girl's Reformatory.
Justice of the Peace vol. 26 no. 2 (11 January 1862) 27-28.

The University of Oxford is the oldest university in the English speaking world. It is said to have been founded in Oxford, England the last decade of the eleventh century, c. 1096.
"Introduction and History," University of Oxford, accessed July 14, 2015, http://www.ox.ac.uk/about/organisation/history.
Fischbacher and Sandoz was a publishing firm in Paris, and also had branch houses in Neuchatel and Geneva.

org.orgName: Association for Promoting the General Welfare of the Blind
org.note: The Association for Promoting the General Welfare of the Blind was founded by Elizabeth Gilbert first as a private undertaking in 1854 and it grew into an association in 1856. Its purpose was to give blind people employment and train them in industrial occupations.

The Brothers Grimm comprised of brothers Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm. During the 1800s they collected and publsihed folklore tales. The brothers became well-known storytellers of folk tales and popularized stories such as "Cinderella", "The Frog Prince", and "Sleeping Beauty".
The Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres is a French society for the support and promotion of the humanities. It was founded in 1663.
London University was founded in 1826 as an alternative to Oxford and Cambridge. Dinah's brother Ben studied Mathematics, Latin, and Natural Philosophy at the University of London beginning in 1848.

The Pottery Mechanics' Institution was an adult educational institution located in Dinah's home town, Stoke-upon-Trent, Staffordshire. The area was once considered the English centre of ceramic manufacturing.
J.B. Davis, Pottery Mechanics' Institution: A Brief Delineation of the Purposes and Advantages of a Class for Mutual Improvement (Hanley: W. Rawley, 1836).
Steven Shapin, "The Pottery Philosophical Society, 1819-1835: An Examination of the Cultural Uses of Provincial Science, Science Studes 2 (4): 311-336.

The Royal Literary Fund is an organized scheme of assistance for writers in financial difficulty. It was established in the late eighteenth-century and is based in London.
Bradford A. Booth, "Trollope and the Royal Literary Fund," Nineteenth Century Fiction 7.3 (December 1952): 208-216, doi: 10.2307/3044361.
"About the RLF," Royal Literary Fund, https://www.rlf.org.uk/.

Phoenix was a major insurance company based in London. George Lovell was Phoenix's secretary for many years.
ODNB.
The London Joint Stock Bank was one of the first joint stock banks in London, meaning that it was owned by multiple shareholders instead of by a single private company. It operated from 1836 to 1918.
The Fields' were the family of James and Annie Fields. They lived in Boston.
The Marshalls were a family that lived in Hampstead Heath.

Wilson, Sons & Company is a Brazilian international shipping company. It was founded by two Scottish brothers in Bahia in 1837, and became established in London eight years later. In its early years, the company was dedicated to the transatlantic shipping of coal.
Geoffrey Jones, "Foundations," Merchants to Multinationals: British Trading Companies in the Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries (Oxford UP, 2000), 28.
"Our History," Wilsons, Sons Group, 2016, http://www.wilsonsons.com.br/our-history, accessed 29 May 2017.

Easton & Amos was a famous Victorian engineering company that primarily manufactured engines and steam machinery. They were based in Southwark, London.
"Easton & Amos," Grace's Guide to British Industrial History, 2016, http://www.gracesguide.co.uk/Easton_and_Amos, accessed 30 May 2017.

org.orgName: Mr. and Mrs. German Reed's Entertainment
org.note:
Mr. and Mrs. German Reed's Entertainment was a group of travelling entertainers employed by the husband and wife duo, Thomas and Priscilla German Reed. The troupe included singers, musician, actors/actresses, and impersonators.
ODNB.
The Royal Family were the relatives of Queen Victoria.

The Army Works Corps was a semi-military organization sent to undertake building in the Crimean war. The AWC was composed largely of tradesmen and engineers. Ben Mulock worked as a ganger in charge of a group of navvies with the AWC in the Crimea.

place.note: The Corner House was Dinah's most important residence, where she lived from 1869 until her death. It was built by the architecht Norman Shaw.
84 Addison Road is an address in Kensington, London.
Arran Cottage was a holiday home that Dinah Craik frequented in the Isle of Arran.
Bahia is a state in Eastern Brazil. Benjamin Mulock worked as a civil engineer photographing the railway in Bahia from c. 1860 to c. 1862.
Baker Street is a street in central London. Frederic Chapman and his family might have had an address on Baker Street.
Bristo Street was a street in Edinburgh where Dinah's friend Mrs. Longstaff lived. The street has since been demolished.
Bootle-cum-Linacre (Linacre) was a small hamlet located near Liverpool.
Dunblane is a small town in central Scotland.
Edinburgh is the capital city of Scotland.
Eden Cottage on Wickham Road was home to the family of Francis Miers. Eden Cottage was very short walking distance away from distance the Corner House.
Farnham is a town in Surrey, England.
33 George Square was the address of the Patons in Edinburgh.
The London office of Macmillan & Co publishing was located at 23 Henrietta Street.
The Isle of Wight is a small island off the Southern coast of England. In the nineteenth century it was a popular holiday resort for middle- and upper-class Victorians.
Kensington is a district of west-central London.
Kentish Town is a district of northwest London.
Kippenross is a geographic barony located near Dunblane, Scotland.
Lancashire is a historic county in northwestern England. In the nineteenth century, Lancashire was a major industrial centre.
Largo is a Scottish fishing village that borders the Firth of Forth.
Fife is a county of southern Scotland between the Firth of Tay and the Firth of Forth.

Liverpool is a Northwestern English city located in the historic county of Lancashire. Dinah lived in Liverpool with her brother Ben Mulock from 1858 to 1859.
Alexander, Lynn M., ed, "Dinah Mulock Craik: A Brief Chronology," John Halifax, Gentleman (Peterborough ON: Broadview, 2005), 25-27.
12 Melville Terrace is an address in Edinburgh.
Pall Mall is a street in west-central London. Hodgson & Graves had an office at 6 Pall Mall.
Piccadilly is a road in west-central London. Chapman and Hall had an office at 193 Piccadilly.
Surrey is a county in southeastern England.
The Temple Lodge is a lodging in Hammersmith, London where Dinah visited occasionally.
Torriano Avenue is a street in Kentish Town.

Upper Tooting is a district of Southern London. Alexander Macmillan of Macmillan & Co owned a spacious house in Upper Tooting where he regularly entertained and lodged friends and authors.
ODNB.
"Mr. Alexander Macmillan," Publishers Circular 58, no. 1385 (1893): 57.
Seiler, Robert M. ed., "The House of Macmillan," The Beautiful Book: Walter Pater and the House of Macmillan, (London UK: Bloomsbury, 2013), 29-35.
In the nineteenth century, Richmond was a town in northwestern Surrey, England.

Sudbrook Park was a hydropathic establishment in Richmond, Surrey. Dr. Edward Wickstead Lane took ownership of Sudbrook Park after leaving Moor Park in 1860.
Frederick Burkhardt et al., eds., The Correspondence of Charles Darwin 13 (New York: Cambridge UP, 2002): 417n7, n9.
Kate Summerscale, Mrs. Robinson's Disgrace: The Private Diary of a Victorian Woman, (New York: Bloomsbury, 2012): 60, 184.

Upper Terrace Lodge was the residence of Miss Coates in Hampstead.
“David Gray’s First Proof-Sheet,” The Irish Monthly 15, (1887): 425.
In the nineteenth century, Amberley was a village in Sussex, England.
In the nineteenth century, Beckenham was a parish near Bromley, Kent. It was about 16 kilometres south-southeast of London.
In the nineteenth century, Bloomsbury was a district of Northwest London, just east of Camden Town.
Burton Crescent was a street in Bloomsbury, near Camden Town.
Dorset is a county in southwest England that borders the English channel.
Mabledon Place was a street in Bloomsbury, near Camden Town.
Oxford Street is a major street in west London.
Pmalder Cottage was a property in Greenock that belonged to Allan Park Paton. Dinah stayed at Pmalder Cottage in late 1850.."County Directory of Scotland (1868)," 278.

The Princess's Theatre was London's leading theatre from 1850-1859, under the management of Charles Kean. It was located in West London on Oxford Street.
M. Glen Wilson, "Kean, Charles John (1811-1868)," ODNB.
John Westland Marston had an address at 22 Rochester Road, Camden Road Villas around the year 1850.
Rose Cottage was a holiday home in Amberley that belonged to a Mr. and Mrs. Guild. Dinah stayed with the Guilds in the 1850s.

15 Sandyford Place was the residence of James and Margaret Craik in Glasgow.
"General Directory: Craig.-Cramb.," Post Office Glasgow Directory for 1863, 1864, (Glasgow: William McKenzie, 1863), 98.
Wareham is a town in Dorset, England.

The Watt Monument was a name used semi-interchangeably with the prestigious Greenock Library. It was a large well-funded scientific library characterized by its memorial statue to James Watt, the library’s first and principal benefactor.
"Watt Library," Inverclyde's History, accessed July 29, 2015. http://www.inverclydeheritage.org.uk/watt-library/.
In the nineteenth century, Sussex was a county in the south of England. It has since been divided into East and West Sussex, and is referred to as a historic county.

Dinah lodged at Chilchester Lodge, Beckenham, Kent in 1866 with her new husband, George Craik.
Alexander, Lynn M., ed, "Dinah Mulock Craik: A Brief Chronology," John Halifax, Gentleman (Peterborough ON: Broadview, 2005), 25-27.
Corrie is a village on the Isle of Arran where the Craiks's friends the Noel-Paton's stayed.
Sannox is a village on the Isle of Arran where the Craiks's friends the Noel-Paton's stayed.
The Grove, Charlton Kings, was one of the homes of the Craik's good friends, the Dobells.
Detmore was the residence of the Dobell family, now a bed and breakfast of the same name. See http://www.detmorehouse.com/.
1 Doune Terrace was the address of the publisher Robert Chambers in Edinburgh's Georgian New Town. Dinah stayed with Robert Chambers and his family at this address on more than one occasion.
Wildwood was Dinah's beloved cottage on Hampstead Heath.
Dinah had two residences on Hampstead Heath, Upper Terrace Cottage and most importantly, Wildwood. In the nineteenth century, Hampstead Heath was much further out than it is today.
Dinah and her family moved to London when she was 14, in 1840. With the exception of a short residence in Wemyss Bay, Craik lived in London and its suburbs for the rest of her life.
Upper Terrace Cottage was Dinah's brief residence in Hampstead Heath, where she and Ben lived before moving to Wildwood Cottage.
Dinah lived in Lynover cottage with two other young women, likely May James and Minna Lovell.
Dinah fled to Wemyss Bay after the death of her brother Ben in 1863. It was here that she rekindled her romance with George Craik.
Arran or "the Isle of Arran" is an island off the western coast of Scotland.

Dinah's Mulock Aunts lived in Bath, and she was married from one of their houses in Bath. She often went to visit her Mulock aunts in the Spring, bringing her daughter Dorothy on more than one occasion.
Alderley Edge was a village in Cheshire, England.
Tewkesbury was a medieval market town in in Gloucestershire, England, and the basis for Norton Bury in John Halifax, Gentleman
A town in Surrey, England.
Dover is a town and major port in Kent, England. Dinah Craik owned a cottage in Dover.
9 Herbert Terrace was the address of Craik's cottage in Dover.
Chatham is a town in Kent, England.
King's Cross is a railway station in London.

Bedford Place was the location of the the Macmillan Publishing Firm in London, where George Craik worked. The street is now known as Bedford Gardens.
"Bedford Gardens to Uxbridge Street: The Racks," Survey of London vol. 37, Northern Kensington (London County Council, 1973) 77–78, via. British History Online.
Eglinton is a village in Londonderry, northern Ireland.
The Pilkington family seat in County Westmeath, Ireland.
Tyrrellspass is a village in County Westmeath, Ireland.
Westmeath is a county in Ireland.
Brompton is a district of west-central London located near the South end of the Kensington Gardens.
Dinah moved to 18 Camden Street North, Camden Town in November 1851.
Camden Town is a district of northwest London.
Clareville Cottage was the dwelling of Edward Chapman's family. It was located in Brompton, London.
Kilburn is a district of northwest London.
Leipzig was a city in the Kingdom of Prussia and is now part of modern Germany. Leipzig was the location of the Prussian publishing house, Tauchnitz.
Paris is the capital city of France.
Renfrewshire is a historic county in the west-central Scottish lowlands.
Sutherland is a county in the Scottish highlands.
Stafford is a county town in Staffordshire.
Staffordshire is a county in the west English midlands.
Balaklava was a city in the Crimean Peninsula. Balaklava was the site of a major battle during the Crimean War (1853-1856).
Belfast is the capital city of Northern Ireland. In the nineteenth century, before the partition of Ireland (1920), Belfast was one of the country's most populous industrial cities.
Birmingham is a city in the West Midlands of England. In the nineteenth century, Birmingham was an industrial and commercial centre.
26 Brecknock Street was an address in Camden New Town, just off of Camden Street and crossing the tracks of the North London Railway. Dinah lodged here sometime in the late 1840s.
5 Brecknock Crescent was an address in Camden New Town slightly northeast of Brecknock Street.
Brecknock Terrace was a street in Camden New Town.
Camden New Town was a district of London just east of Camden Town.
Camden Road was a major road in Camden Town.
In the nineteenth century, 7 Mornington Crescent was an address in Camden Town South.

The nineteenth-century Stationers' Hall was a building in central London owned by The Stationers' Company of London. Stationers' Hall still exists today.
"The Hall & Heritage," The Stationers' Company, accessed Aug. 3, 2015. https://stationers.org/the-hall-heritage.html.
"The Stationers' Hall," The Stationers' Company, accessed Aug. 3, 2015.https://stationers.org/the-hall-heritage/the-stationers-hall.html.
Brighton is a town on the south coast of England.

Fairfield is a town in the county of Surrey, England. Samuel Carter Hall purchased a country home in Fairfield in 1849.
ODNB.
"List of Members," Surrey Archaeological Collections 1, (1858): 43.
In the nineteenth century, Ireland was yet to be partitioned. Ireland formed a part of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.
Oxford is a city in Southeast England.
Saltley is a district of central Birmingham.

place.placeName: Italy Kingdom of Sardinia Piedmont-Sardinia Kingdom of Italy
place.note: The Kingdom of Sardinia was an early European state (c. 1324-1861) and a predecessor to modern Italy. In 1861, the Kingdom of Sardinia was unified with the rest of Italy and was thus renamed the Kingdom of Italy.
Donegal is a town in County Donegal, Ireland.
Cushendall is a village in County Antrim, northern Ireland.
Curran is a small village in County Londonderry, northern Ireland.
Sir Noel Paton used to stay at Corin Manor in September.
Kilnagarna is a place in Ireland where the Mulock’s had a residence
Athlone is a village in Ireland.
Lough Eske Castle is located in County Donegal in the northwest of Ireland.
In the nineteenth century, Dublin was the capital of Ireland.
Castletown is a village on the north coast of the Highland in Scotland
Lodges located in Athlone, County Westmeath, Ireland.
Slieve League is a mountain located on the coast of County Donegal, Ireland.
Llanfairfechan is a town in the Conwy County Borough of Wales
Loch Fyne is a sea loch located on the west coast of Argyll and Bute, Scotland.
Derry is a city in northern Ireland.
York is a city in North Yorkshire, England. The Flying Scotsman, the train from King's Cross Station, London, to Edinburgh Waverley, stopped there for lunch from 1862 to 1888.
Morvern is a peninsula in western Scotland.
Dalmally is a village in Scotland.
In the nineteenth century, Greenock was a burgh in the historic county of Renfrewshire. Dinah sometimes stayed with Allan Park Paton in Greenock.
Winchester is a cathedral town in southern England.
Hammersmith is a district in West London.
Bristol is a town in southwest England on the River Avon.
Alexandria is a major port city in northern Egypt.
Teignmouth is a town in south Devon, England.
Devon is a county in southwest England.
The ruins of Corfe Castle are situated in the county of Dorset in southwest England, near Swanage.
Swanage is a coastal town in southwest England.

Geneva is a city in western Switzerland. At the beginning of the nineteenth century Geneva was occupied by France but at the end of the Napoleonic Wars (1815) it became part of the Swiss Confederation.

Switzerland (formerly the Swiss Confederation) began the nineteenth century as a as a territory of Napoleonic France. It went through a period of Restoration/Reformation after the end of the Napoleonic Wars, and ended the century as an independent nation-state following the drafting of a formal Constitution in 1848.
Nice is a city in the south of France. From 1814 to 1843 Nice was part of the Kingdom of Sardinia. It was reannexed by France in 1860.

Dieppe is a coastal town in northern France. Because of its position on the England channel, Dieppe was (and still is) a major port town and was important to the exchange of goods and people in the nineteenth century.
In the nineteenth century, Leamington was a spa town in central England.

Plymouth is a city on the southwest coast of England. In the nineteenth century, Plymouth was a major port city. It was a site for the import and export of goods as well as the departure point for many naval expeditions.
In the nineteenth century, "New Sydney" was the name attributed to the city that is now Sydney, Australia.
The lands of Finnart once formed a barony to the west of Greenock. By the nineteenth century, they had been dissolved and divided between Gourock and west Greenock.
In the nineteenth century, Gourock was a small burgh in the county of Renfrewshire, just west of Greenock.
In the nineteenth century, Longsight was a chapelry near Manchester.
Manchester is a city in northwest England. In the nineteenth century, it was a major industrial center.
Cheltenham is a spa town in western England.
Charlton Kings is a suburb of Cheltenham.

Detmore House, Charlton Kings, was the family home of the Dobells.
"Directory of the Principal Gentry in the County of Gloucester," The Cheltenham Annuaire for 1875 (Cheltenham, Henry Davies, 1875), 80.
Chelsea is a district of southwest London. In the nineteenth century, it had a reputation as London's bohemian quarter.

16 Tite Street was the home of Oscar Wilde in Chelsea, London. Since Wilde's time, the house has been renumbered to 34 Tite Street.
E.H. Mikail, ed., Oscar Wilde: Interviews and Recollections 2 (London: Macmillan, 1979).
John Freeman, Literature and Locality: The Literary Topography of Britain and Ireland (London: Casell, 1963), 43.

In the nineteenth century, Cromarty was a county town and seaport in the Scottish Highlands. It was a well-established port for emigrants.
Lucille H. Campey, Fast Sailing and Copper-Bottomed: Aberdeen Sailing Ships and the Emigrant Scots They Carried to Canada, 1774-1855 (Toronto: Natural Heritage/Natural History Inc., 2002), 57–58.
Orkney is an archipelago off the northeastern coast of Scotland.
Ramsgate is a seaside town in east Kent, England.
Leckhampton is a district of south Cheltenham.
Melbourne is a city in southeastern Australia.
St. Andrews was once a royal burgh in eastern Fife, Scotland.
Cambridge is a university city in southeastern England.
Hammersmith Bridge crosses the River Thames in west London.
The River Thames flows through southern England and is well-known for crossing through the capital, London.
Niton is a small village on the Isle of Wight, England.
Wapping is a district of east London.
The Netherlands is a country in northwestern Europe.
Neuchâtel is a French-speaking city in Switzerland. It lies on the northern shore of Lake Neuchâtel.
Armitage is a small village in Staffordshire.
Kingsley is a small village in Staffordshire.
The Strand is a major street in west-central London.
St. John's Wilderness, more commonly known as the Backs, is a scenic area in the city of Cambridge.
Trinity Avenue is in the city of Cambridge.
Oban is a town in the Argyll and Bute area of Scotland where Dinah would often go for a holiday.

Collin's Farm or the Wylde's Farmhouse was a fashionable farmhouse resort located near Wildwood and Hampstead Heath. Charles Dickens stayed at Collin's Farm around May 1837. Norman Page, ed. Charles Dickens: Family History, volume 5 (New York: Routledge, 1999), 1837, Web.
Ayr is a town and former Royal Burgh on the southwest coast of Scotland. It is near the Isle of Arran, where Dinah had a holiday home.

Macmillan Co. was located on Trinity Street in Cambridge from 1843 to 1863. They were at 17 Trinity Street for the first three years, and then at 1 Trinity Street from 1846 onwards. There were living quarters at both addresses.
Charles L. Graves, Life and Letters of Alexander Macmillan (London: Macmillan, 1910), 26-29.
The Lakes District is a region of northwest England. It was a popular holiday destination in the nineteenth century and featured prominently in the poems by William Wordsworth and other Lake Poets.
Rydal is a village northeast of Ambleside in the Lakes District.
Ambleside is a town in the Lakes District of northwest England.
1 Camden Park Road, Camden Park Villas was the address of John Westland Marston in London.
Whitby is a seaside town in Yorkshire, northern England.
15 Norfolk Buildings was the address of Dinah's aunts in west-central Bath.
13 Great Marlborough Street was the office of the publishers Hurst & Blackett in west London.
Geelong is a port city in southern Australia. The city experienced a boom period during the Victorian gold rush of the 1850s.
Bayswater is a residential area in west-central London close to the Kensington Gardens.

Margaret Oliphant and her family lived on Bayswater Road for a short time in 1865 while they looked for a home to rent in Windsor.
Margaret Oliphant, "Margaret Oliphant: A Brief Chronology," Autobiography of Margaret Oliphant, ed. Elisabeth Jay (Broadview P, 2002), 169.
Beckenham Church was the main Anglican parish church in Beckenham, Kent. It is also known as St. George's Church.
Birkenhead is a town in Merseyside, England, across the river from Liverpool.
Claughton is a residential district in Birkenhead.
13 Bath Street, Claughton, Birkenhead was one of Margaret Oliphant's many addresses near Liverpool.
In the nineteenth century, Kensington Station was a major railway station in west-central London.
In the nineteenth century, Balham Station was a railway station in south London.
Clapham Junction Station is a major railway station in Battlesea, southwest London

Chalcots was a sub-division of Hampstead Heath, – once called the Chalcots estate. The estate was developed for mass residency in the early nineteenth century and became home to families such as the De Morgans.
T F T Baker, Diane K Bolton and Patricia E C Croot. "Hampstead: Chalcots," in A History of the County of Middlesex: Volume 9, Hampstead, Paddington, ed. C R Elrington (London: Victoria County History, 1989), 63-66. British History Online, accessed May 5, 2017, Web.
Avignon is a city in southeastern France.
Barton-under-Needwood is a village near Lichfield in Staffordshire, England. Dinah's family friend Mrs Wilson lived in Barton-under-Needwood in 1845.

Lichfield is a city in Staffordshire, England. In the mid-1840s, Dinah's maternal aunt, Emma Mellard Parker, and her family lived at Lysways Hall near Lichfield.
Reade, The Mellards & Their Descendants, 18-20.
In the nineteenth-century, Willesden was a parish in Middlesex, near London.
Urquhart could refer to any of four areas in Scotland, one of which is in Fife.
Cornwall is a ceremonial county on the westernmost point of the southwest penninsula of the United Kingdom.
Ventnor, on the Isle of Wight, is a seaside resort and parish.
Shanklin is where Holme Lee lived on the Isle of Wight.
Southampton is a city south-west of London on the south coast of England.
Bradford is a city in West Yorkshire, England
Oldfield is a small hamlet in West Yorkshire, England
Aldworth was Lord Tennyson's house in Blackdown, West Sussex.
Farringford House was Lord Alfred Tennyson's main residence, located on the Isle of Wight.
Freshwater is a large village and parish on the western end of the Isle of Wight, and was popularised as a coastal resort town in the Victorian era.
London Victoria Station is a central London Underground and train station which operates trains to Kent.
The Clock House was the address of Miss Montgomery in Hampstead Heath. Laura Herford lived here while attending the Royal Academy.
St. Paul's Cathedral is an Anglican cathedral in east-central London. It is one of the city's major landmarks.

Watling Street is a major ancient road that, in the nineteenth century, ran from Dover to London. The London Fire Brigade (formerly the London Fire Engine Establishment) used to be located on 68 Watling Street.
H. Waddington, "Copy of the Letter from the Secretary of the London Fire Brigade, dated the 21st day of February 1862, addressed to the Secretary of State for the Home Department," Accounts and Papers of the House of Commons vol. XLVII (1862): 243.
London Bridge Station is a major railway station located in south-central London on Tooley Street.
Eaton Square is a garden square in west London. Since the nineteenth century, Eaton Square has been primarily a residential area for the upper classes.
Leicester is a city in east-central England.
Bruges is the capital city of Belgium. In the latter half of the nineteenth century, Bruges was a popular tourist destination for the British upper classes.

Tooley Street was a riverside street in south-central London. A warehouse on Cotton's Wharf, Tooley Street was the ignition site of the Tooley Street Fire of 1861.
"The Great Fire," Times (London), June 25, 1861, pg. 9; Issue 23968.

In the nineteenth century, Bombay (now Mumbai) was a major trading city in India.
Chakravarthi Raghavan, "Mumbai, India," Encyclopaedia Britannica, Web.
Bermondsey is a district of southeast London, bordering the Thames.
The Lord Warden House is a luxury hotel that opened in Dover in 1853. It was named after the then Duke of Wellington, who was Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports.
Brackley Villas, Dulwich was the address of the famous English singer W. H. Cummings in 1876.
Dulwich is an area of southeast London in Southwark.
Ardway seems to have once been a hamlet near Arrochar in Scotland. There is no longer a town by this name in the area.
Arrochar is a Scottish village located at the northernmost point of Loch Long, and just west of Tarbet, Loch Lomond.
Tarbet is a Scottish village located on the west shore of Loch Lomond.
Loch Lomond is a large freshwater loch in central Scotland, northwest of Glasgow. Sir Joseph Noel Paton and his family spent some of their holidays at Loch Lomond.
Swinford House, Ashford, Kent was the address of Dinah's paternal cousin, Hester Jane Austin.
Ashford is a market town located southeast of London in the county of Kent.
9 Hubert Terrace was the address of Dinah's seaside house in Dover. Dinah purchased 9 Hubert Terrace around 1875.
27 Bedford Gardens, Kensington was an address where Dinah's brother-in-law Henry Craik was staying in London in 1874.
Campden Hill is an area of high ground between Holland Park and the Kensington Gardens. It is located across from the Kensington Palace in London.
The Clock House was the address of Francis Tress Barry and Sarah Barry in Beckenham from around 1872 to 1875.
Downshire Hill is a popular residential street in east-central Hampstead.
The Pyrenees is a mountain range that divides France and Spain.
For most of the nineteenth century, Portobello was a seaside burgh near Edinburgh. It was incorporated into the city in 1896.
Balmoral is a castle in Aberdeenshire, Scotland. It has been one of the Royal residences since 1852.
Rio de Janeiro is a major municipality in southern Brazil. Rio was Brazil's capital city for most of the nineteenth century.
Petropólis is a municipality in southern Brazil. It was the summer residence of the Brazilian ruling and upper-classes during the nineteenth century.
Llandudno is a seaside town in northern Wales, located on the Creuddyn peninsula. In the latter half of the nineteenth century, it was a popular resort town.
Southend-on-sea (known commonly as Southend) was a popular seaside resort town in the nineteenth century. It is located in southern Essex.

Cleeve Tower was the summer residence of Sydney Dobell. It stood on Cleeve Hill, the tallest of the Cotswald Hills. He took possession in 1858.
John Nichol, ed., The Poetical Works of Sydney Dobell, vol. 1 (London: Smith, Elder, & Co., 1875), xxiv.
Sydney Dobell, Poems (Boston: Ticknor & Fields, 1860), ix.
The Cotswolds is a rural area of south-central England. The area is known for its grasslands and its rolling hills.
Norfolk is a county in eastern England.
The Velino is a river in central Italy.
The Cloaca Maxima is a series of Roman aqueducts that served as one of the first modern sewage systems.

For most of the nineteenth century, Putney was a parish in the county of Surrey, situated west of London on the banks of the Thames. It was the site of the College for Civil Engineers beginning in 1840.
In the nineteenth century, Mortlake was a parish in the county of Surrey, situated west of Putneyon the banks of the Thames. It is the historic end point of the annual Oxford vs. Cambridge boat race.
Windsor is a town west of London on the River Thames.
Speke Hall is a famous Tudor manor house and a landmark in the city of Liverpool.
Canonbury is a district of Islington and a suburb of north London.
Pond Street Station was a nineteenth-century train station close to Hampstead Heath on Pond Street.
Hamilton is a town in the central Lowlands of Scotland.

Blackgang Chine is a large chine (i.e. a deep and narrow sea-side ravine) on the southern coast of the Isle of Wight just west of Niton. In the Victorian era, Blackgang Chine was a holiday retreat with natural spring waters, rugged landscapes, and a unique fin-whale skeleton display.
"The Common Fin-Whale," Cassell's Popular Natural History: Mammalia vol. 1 (London: Cassell, Petter, & Galpin, 1863), 369.
Tourist's Guide Through the Isle of Wight (London: Simpkin, Marshall, & Co., 1846), 71-72; 197-198.
Hatton Garden is a district of Camden Town, London.
St. Pancras is an Anglican church in central London located near Euston Station.
In the nineteenth century, Haverstock Hill was a road running northwest by southeast between Camden Town and Hampstead.
The Bay of Biscay is a gulf off of the Atlantic Ocean, situated to the west of France and to the north of Spain.
Ilfracombe is a seaside town in North Devon, England.

The North Bank Priory was George Henry Lewes and Marian Evans's house in Regents Park.
ODNB.
Regents Park is one of the Royal Parks in north-west central London.
31 Onslow Square is an address in Kensington, London. This may have been the address of Frances Martin.
Bryntysilto is an area in Wales.
Llangollen is a small town in northeast Wales.
Finchley Road is an address in London. This may have been the address of Emma Sherrington.
Burnham House is an eighteenth-century detached house in Buckinghamshire, north of London.
Salisbury is a cathedral city in Wiltshire, England
St. Paul is a American city in Minnesota.
Minnesota is a state in the United States
Lansdowne is an address in Birmingham.
Edgbaston is a suburban area in Central Birmingham, England. The lack of factories in the area made it attractive to the middle classes in the nineteenth-century.
Lowndes Square is a residential garden square in Belgravia, southwest London.
North End was a neighbourhood in the same area as Wildwood in Hampstead.
Prittlewell is a town within a district of the same name in Essex.
Bethesda is a town in northwest Wales.
Val-Richer was Francois Guizot's estate in Normandy, France.
Carrick is a small town in the parish of Glencolmcille in County Donegal, Ireland.
Donegal, also known as Tyrconnell, is a county in the north of Ireland.
Mount Blanc, located between Italy and France, is the highest mountain in the Alps.
Charing Cross is a railway station in London.
Venice is a city in Italy.
Bideford is a port town in north Devon.
North Tawton is a small town in Devon.
Ashkelon is a coastal city in Israel, and the Battle of Ascalon was considered the last action of the First Crusade. The city dates back to the Neolithic era.
17 Courtfield Road was the residence of Mrs. Hamilton in South Kensington
Queen's Gate Gardens appears to be the address of the Kingsfords, Dinah's former neighbours.
Baden, according to Dinah, is a coastal area in Devon, 24 miles from Bideford.
Pembroke College, founded in 1624, is one of the constituent colleges of the University of Oxford. It is the sister college of Queens College, Cambridge.
Pembroke College is the third oldest college at the University of Cambridge, and was founded in 1347. Queens College, Oxford is its sister college.
Upper Deal is a hamlet in Kent.
Crewe is a railway town and civil parish in Chesire.
5 Via Montebello was the Italian address of the Pension Girard, and was extremely popular with English visitors.
Florence is a city in Italy, and was one of the major Renaissance cities.
Sandhurst is a village in Berkshire.
72 Via Sistina is an Italian address, which appears to be the resisdence of "Contessa".
Parkstone is a village in Dorset.
The Hermitage is the residence of Mrs. Skelton. It is most likely in the Hermitage of Braid near Edinburgh.
The Hermitage of Braid is the area between the Braid Hills and Blackford Hill near Edinburgh.
Beckingham Palace is a mansion in Hertfordshire.
Amy Cottage appears to be the Springfields' residence in Stratford-upon-Avon.
4 Chandos Road appears to be the address of George and Mary Springfield. It is located in Stratford-upon-Avon.
Stratford-upon-Avon is a market town in Warwickshire, England.
Mountfield appears to be the residence of Mrs. Russell Keyhold.
Child's Hill is an address in southern London, near Charing Cross.
35 Hyde Park Garden was the Londonstreet address of Edward Fordham Flower.
Deal Road is an address in Dover.
Dover Castle is a medieval castle in Dover, Kent. It is the largest stronghold in England.
Connaught Park was the first park established in Dover in the Victorian era.
In the nineteenth century, New Zealand was a British colony with its own responsible government.
Wellington has been the capital city of New Zealand since 1865.
Cirencester is a town in east Gloucestershire, south of Charlton Kings..
Cresswell is a hamlet in Staffordshire slightly east of Dinah's home town Stoke-upon-Trent.
Heath Street runs north-south to the west of Hampstead Heath in London.
In the nineteenth century, Frognal was an area of west Hampstead.
In the nineteenth century, Holt Hill was a town in Cheshire, northwest England.
The Mersey is a river in northwest England that widens into an estuary at Liverpool.
Aldershot is a town in Hampshire. It is slightly northeast of Farnham.

Hale Church was the village church of Hale, near Farnham, Surrey. It was erected in the 1840s.
"Church-building News," The Builder (1 August 1868): 578.
Crawfordsburn is a village situated off the eastern coast of the Belfast Lough in what is now Northern Ireland. It is slightly northeast of Belfast.
Cave Hill is situated to the north-northwest of Belfast.

The Scottish Highlands refers to the areas of Scotland north of the Highland Boundary Fault. This area is known for its rugged mountains and pine forests. In the nineteenth century, this area was less populated than the Lowlands due to the Higland Clearances, industrialization and urbanization.
In the nineteenth century, Leith was a burgh located north of Edinburgh at the mouth of the Water of Leith.
Snowdon is the highest mountain in Wales.
In the nineteenth century, Walton was a town to the north of Liverpool and east of Linacre. It is now part of the city borough.
Windsor Castle is one of the residences of the Royal Family.
10 Via Delle Quattro Fontaine is an address in Rome where Dinah stayed in 1884.
Mortola or Mortola Inferiore is a village in Liguria, Italy. Dinah and her family visited Mortola during their trip to Italy in 1880.
"Stoke Church" was the colloquial name for the parish church in Dinah's hometown, Stoke-upon-Trent.

place.placeName: The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland
The United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

place.note: Ludgate Hill is located in the city of London
Holland is a region and former province on the western coast of the Netherlands, and is also used to refer to the Netherlands in general.
Syria is a country in the Middle East.
Bonchurch is a small village in the southern region of the Isle of Wight.
Stonehenge is a prehistoric monument of standing stones. It is located 3km west of Wiltshire, and was built between 3000BCE and 2000BCE.

The Britannia Theatre was a working class theatre on High Street, Hoxton. Colin Hazelwood was the resident dramatist of the theatre.
Victorian Web.
2 Mount Pleasant Court was the address of Dinah Mulock.
West Wickham is a suburban area in southern London, near Charing Cross.
Londrina is a city in the north of the state of Paraná, Brazil.

event.label: The Tooley Street Fire
The Great Fire of Tooley Street
event.note:
The Tooley Street Fire of 22 June 1861 was a devastating fire that started on Tooley Street, London. The fire claimed the life of James Braidwood, the superintendent of the London Fire Engine Establishement. Many claimed that the Tooley Street Fire was the worst London fire since the Great Fire of London in 1666.
"The Great Fire," Times (London), Tuesday, June 25, 1861, pg. 9; Issue 23968.

event.label: The Great Fire of London
event.note: The Great Fire of 1666 burned down the majority of central London. It started shortly after midnight at a bakery on Pudding Lane.

msIdentifier.repository: Charles E Young Research Library, University of California at Los Angeles
Manuscripts Division, Department of Rare Books and Special Collections, Princeton University Library
msIdentifier.collection: M. L. Parrish Collection of Victorian Novelists

msIdentifier.repository: Literary and Historical Manuscripts, The Morgan Library and Museum.
Berg Collection, New York Public Library
msIdentifier.collection: Dinah Maria Mulock Craik Collection of Papers

bibl.title: The Youth's Instructor
bibl.author: Ellen White
James White
bibl.note: The Youth's Instructor was a weekly publication for children and youth managed by the Seventh-Day Adventists.

bibl.title: The International Review
bibl.note: The International Review was an American publication that largely focused on articles, essays, and book reviews. They invited Dinah to write for them around 1878.

bibl.title: Temple Bar: A London Magazine for Town and Country Readers
Aunt Judy's Magazine
bibl.note:
Aunt Judy's Magazine was a British children's magazine titled after the nickname of Juliana Gatty. It often focused on moral tales for children, and contributors included Juliana Ewing, Hans Christian Andersen, and Lewis Carroll.
ODNB.

bibl.title: The Charm
bibl.note: The Charm was a children's periodical published by Addey & Co.

bibl.title: Howitt's Journal
bibl.note: Howitt's was a weekly periodical launched by William Howitt in 1847. The journal went bankrupt in 1848.

bibl.title: Douglas Jerrold's Shilling Magazine
bibl.note: Jerrold's was a monthly magazine brought out by Bradbury and Evans that ran from 1845 to 1848. The magazine was similar in tone to Punch and had overlapping contributors.

bibl.title: The Welcome Guest
bibl.note:
The Welcome Guest catered to a wide readership, and contained a variety of content including poems and illustrations.
Victorian Web.

bibl.title: Bentley's Miscellany
bibl.note: Bentley's Miscellany was a popular Victorian periodical founded by Richard Bentley and edited by Charles Dickens.

bibl.title: Illustrated News
bibl.note: The Illustrated London News was a weekly news periodical published from 1842 to 1971.

The Art Journal was an influential art magazine based in London. It was edited by Samuel Carter Hall.
Mandler, Peter, "Hall, Samuel Carter (1800-1889)," ODNB.

bibl.title: Once a Week: an Illustrated Miscellany of Literature, Popular Science, and Art
bibl.note:
Once a Week was a weekly illustrated periodical published by Bradbury and Evans between 1859 and 1880.
John Sutherland The Stanford Companion to Victorian Fiction (Stanford: Stanford UP, 1989), 479–480.
“Once a Week,” Rosetti Archive Periodicals, accessed 12 May, 2016, http://www.rossettiarchive.org/docs/ap4.o4.raw.html.

bibl.title: Every Saturday: A Journal of Choice Reading Selected from Foreign Current Literature
bibl.note:
Every Saturday was a weekly periodical published by Ticknor and Fields from 1866 to 1874.
Frank Luther Mott, "Every Saturday," A History of American Magazines 1865–1885 (Cambridge MA, Harvard UP, 1938), 357–362.

bibl.title: The Cornhill Magazine
bibl.note:
Cornhill Magazine (1860–1975) was a monthly illustrated periodical published by Smith, Elder & Co. and aimed towards middle-class readers. William Makepeace Thackeray was the magazine's original editor.
ODNB.
Barbara Quinn Schmidt, "'The Cornhill Magazine': Celebrating Success," Victorian Periodical Review 32.3 (Fall 1999): 202–208.

bibl.title: The Atlantic Monthly
bibl.note: The Atlantic Monthly is an American literary and cultural periodical that was founded Boston in 1857. The periodical aimed to attract literary elites, competing with Harper's and its large middle-class readership.

bibl.title: Our Young Folks
bibl.note: Our Young Folks was an illustrated literary periodical for children published weekly by Ticknor & Fields.

bibl.title: The Dial
bibl.note: The Dial was a weekly London newspaper planned by the National Newspaper League Company. It was edited by Peter Bayne from 1860 to 1862, during which time, the paper succeeded but Bayne went bankrupt.

title.foreign: Le Caméléon: ou Recueil Mensuel de Morceaux de Littérature, Sciences, Beaux Arts, Histoire, Géographie, Voyages, etc.

bibl.title: Le Caméléon littéraire
bibl.note: Le Caméléon was a monthly French-language periodical. Some of Dinah's first published works were translations of texts from Le Caméléon.

bibl.title: Chambers's Miscellany of Useful and Entertaining Tracts
bibl.note:
Chambers's Miscellany, was a series of short pamphlets published by William & Robert Chambers from 1844 to 1847. Each pamphlet included stories and poetry that centred around a single topic. Dinah contributed to Chambers's Miscellany early in her career.
Aileen Fyfe, Steam-Powered Knowledge: William Chambers and the Business of Publishing, 1820-1860 (Chicago: University of Chicago P), 75.

bibl.title: Blackwood's Edingburgh Magazine
bibl.note: Blackwood's Magazine was located in Edinburgh. It was founded by the grandfather (and namesake) of William Blackwood.

bibl.title: Household Words
bibl.note: Household Words was a weekly literary magazine edited by Charles Dickens.

bibl.title: Lloyd's List
bibl.note: Lloyd's List is a long-running daily newspaper that focusses on merchants' and maritime news.

bibl.title: The Leader
bibl.note:
The Leader was a radical political newspaper published weekly between 1850 and 1859.
"The Leader (1850-1859)," Nineteenth-Century Serials Edition, 2017, http://www.ncse.ac.uk/headnotes/ldr.html, accessed 31 May 2017.

bibl.title: All the Year Round
bibl.note:
All the Year Round was literary periodical published weekly between 1859 and 1895. It was conducted and edited by Charles Dickens.
"All the Year Round," Dickens Journals Online, U Buckingham 2009, http://www.djo.org.uk/indexes/journals/all-the-year-round.html, accessed 31 May 2017.

bibl.title: The Times
The London Times
bibl.note: The Times is a national British daily newspaper based in London. It has been printed under its current name since 1788.

bibl.title: Revue Des Deux Mondes
bibl.note: Revue Des Deux Mondes is a French language monthly periodical based in Paris. It has been in print since 1829.

bibl.title: Paths of Peace
bibl.note: Paths of Peace was the Christmas special number of the Sunday Magazine.

bibl.title: The National Magazine
bibl.note: The National Magazine was a monthly literary periodical published in London beginning in 1856. Dinah's close family friend Westland Marston was one of its original editors.

bibl.title: Harper's Bazaar
bibl.note: Harper's Bazaar during the Victorian era was a weekly magazine which catered to women in the middle and upper classes, and styled itself as America's first fashion magazine.

bibl.title: The Laurel Bush: Two Little Tinkers
bibl.author: Dinah Mulock Craik
bibl.note: Two Little Tinkers is a supplemental short story added to the end of The Laurel Bush in the Tauchnitz edition.

bibl.title: Light In Darkness
bibl.author: Dinah Mulock Craik
bibl.note: Light in Darkness was an essay published in Dinah's book of essays, Plain Speaking.

bibl.title: A Life for a Life
bibl.note: Colin Hazelwood adapted A Life for a Life as a stage melodrama, and it was performed at Britania Theatre in 1860.

bibl.title: King Arthur: Not a Love Story
A Double House
bibl.note: "A Double House" was originally published in Fraser's Magazine.

bibl.title: How to Win Love, or Rhoda's Lesson
bibl.note: Before settling on a title for "How to Win Love, or Rhoda's Lesson", Dinah Craik appears to have titled this children's tale "Winifred Lee" after one of its central characters.

bibl.title: The Last House in Cecil Street
bibl.note: "The Last House in Cecil Street" was originally published in Fraser's Magazine.

bibl.title: A Low Marriage
bibl.note: "A Low Marriage" was originally published in Fraser's Magazine.

bibl.title: Songs of our Youth
bibl.note:
Songs of our Youth was a collection of Swedish, French, Irish, Gaelic, Welsh, Old English, and original melodies with lyrics by Dinah Mulock Craik. The collection contained original music by B.R.M.— an amateur composer who many believed to be Dinah's deceased brother Benjamin Robert Mulock.
John Hannavy, ed., "Mulock, Benjamin Robert," Encyclopedia of Nineteenth-Century Photography (New York: Routledge, 2008): 959-960, accessed August 12, 2015.
"Music," The Athenaeum, no. 2471 (March 6, 1875): 333. accessed August 11, 2015.
"Music," The Atlantic Monthly 37 (1876): 251-252. accessed August 11, 2015.

bibl.title: A Dreadful Ghost
bibl.note:
"A Dreadful Ghost" was a short story by Dinah Craik published in Once a Week in February 1862. It was later included in volume II of Dinah's 1870 book of short stories, The Unkind Word and Other Stories.
Dinah Craik, The Unkind Word and Other Stories II (London, Hurst & Blackett, 1870), 73–88.
Sally Mitchell, Dinah Mulock Craik (Boston: Twayne Publishers, 1983), 134–135.

bibl.title: The Unkind Word and Other Stories
bibl.note: The Unkind Word and Other Stories was a collection of Dinah Craik's short stories published in two volumes by Hurst and Blackett in 1870.

bibl.title: An Unknown Country
bibl.author: Dinah Mulock Craik
bibl.note: An Unknown Country was a travel narrative recording one of Dinah's trips to northern Ireland. It was published in the English Illustrated Magazine in 1887.

bibl.title: Concerning Men
bibl.note:
