"Concerning Men," was first published anonymously in volume 9 of The Cornhill Magazine (October 1887). In Craik's own words, the essay examines "the mutual limitations of each sex, and its supplementation by the other."
Dinah Mulock Craik, "Concerning Men," The Cornhill Magazine 9.56 (Oct. 1887): 368–377.

bibl.title: A Man's Wooing
bibl.note: "A Man's Wooing" was a short poem by Dinah published in Macmillan's Magazine.

bibl.title: Blind
bibl.note: Blind is an essay found in the November 1860 to April 1861 volume of Macmillan's Magazine in which Dinah recounts a visit to Elizabeth Gilbert's Association for Promoting the General Welfare of the Blind.

bibl.title: Cathair Fhargus (Fergus's Seat)
bibl.note: Cathair Fhargus is a poem by Craik, found in the November 1860 to April 1861 volume of Macmillan's Magazine.

bibl.title: Adventures of a Brownie, as Told to my Child
bibl.note: Adventures of a Brownie was a children's book of short stories about a brownie, a traditional Scottish household creature. Published
This may have shown up in Dinah's novel "The Fairy Book" as "The Six Swans" story.

bibl.title: The Fairy Book: Best Popular Fairy Stories Selected and Rendered Anew
bibl.note: This book by Dinah Mulock Craik was published in 1863. It is a collection of fairy stories from several countries.

bibl.title: Brother Jonathan's Pet
bibl.note: Brother Jonathan's Pet was a short story by Dinah Craik published anonymously in Chambers's Edinburgh Journal on January 16, 1858 (no. 211).

bibl.title: Going Out to Play
bibl.note: Going Out to Play was a short story by Dinah Craik published anonymously in Chambers's Edinburgh Journal on March 6, 1858 (no. 218).

bibl.title: Want Something to Read
bibl.note: Want Something to Read was a short story by Dinah Craik published anonymously in Chambers's Edinburgh Journal on May 8, 1858 (no. 227).

bibl.title: Our Lost Pet
bibl.note: Our Lost Pet was a short story by Dinah Craik published anonymously in Chambers's Edinburgh Journal on May 29, 1858 (no. 230).

bibl.title: A Woman's Thoughts About Women
bibl.note:
A Woman's Thoughts About Women was a women's advice book by Dinah Mulock Craik. The book was a compilation of essays on subjects such as self-dependence, worldliness, and female friendship – all originally published anonymously in Chambers's Edinburgh Journal in 1857. A Woman's Thoughts About Women was published without Dinah's permission in the United States in the same year of its original publication.
Sally Mitchell, Dinah Mulock Craik (Boston: Twayne, 1983), 53-55.

bibl.title: Sophia of Wolfenbuttel
bibl.note: Sophia of Wolfenbuttel was a story that Dinah translated from Italian for publication in Chambers' Edinburgh Journal in 1845. The original story was from an 1816 Italian book by L. Bramieri called the Nouvelle morali di Francesco Soave.

bibl.title: The Sister of Rembrandt: a Flemish Story
bibl.note:
Dinah translated and extended "The Sister of Rembrandt" from the French original in 1845. It appeared in in volume 6 of Chambers' Miscellany. The original was published in the French periodical, Le Caméléon.
"The Sister of Rembrandt: a Flemish Story," Chambers' Miscellany of Useful and Entertaining Tracts vol. 5-6 (Edinburgh: W & R Chambers, 1845) no. 54, Web.

bibl.title: The Story of Elisabetta Sirani
bibl.note: Elisabetta Sirani was a short story from Felsina Pittrice (1841 that Dinah translated in the early 1840s. The translation was originall published in Chambers's Journal in July 1847 and later appeared in Dinah's short story collection Romantic Tales (1857).

bibl.title: The New Teacher
bibl.note: "The New Teacher" was a text that Dinah either wrote or translated for publication by William & Robert Chambers in 1845. It seems to have been rejected.

bibl.title: In A Houseboat
bibl.note: In A Houseboat was a short story published in 1884 by Harpers.

bibl.title: Thirty Years, Being Poems New and Old
bibl.note: This book of poems was published by Macmillan & Co in 1880. Many poems were reprints from Dinah's earlier publications.

bibl.title: The Last Earl of Cairnforth
bibl.note: The Last Earl of Cairnforth was a one volume tale that Craik wanted to appear anonymously in Blackwood's magazine prior to being published as a whole.

bibl.title: Novels and Novel Makers
bibl.note:
On Novels and Novel Makers was an essay by Dinah Craik that was published in Good Words on 1 May 1881. The essay was reprinted in Dinah's 1882 collection of essays, Plain Speaking.
Sally Mitchell, "Selected Bibliography," Dinah Mulock Craik (Boston: Twayne Publishers, 1983), 135-136.

bibl.title: Studies From Life
bibl.note:
Studies from Life was one of Dinah's essay collections. It consisted mainly of reprinted essays published in Chambers's Edinburgh Journal from 1855 to 1858.
Sally Mitchell, "Selected Bibliography," Dinah Mulock Craik (Boston: Twayne Publishers, 1983), 134.

bibl.title: Sermons out of Church
bibl.note:
Sermons our of Church was one of Dinah's essay collections. It consisted of semiphilisophical essays on the topics of proper character and conduct.
Sally Mitchell, "Selected Bibliography," Dinah Mulock Craik (Boston: Twayne Publishers, 1983), 100, 134.

bibl.title: From Over the Sea
bibl.note: From Over the Sea was an essay collection that Dinah proposed for publication by Ticknor & Fields. It doesn't appear to have ever been published. It would have consisted of Dinah's articles on American subjects, all originally published by Ticknor & Fields (most likely in Our Young Folks).

bibl.title: Running Away: A Schoolmaster's Story
bibl.note: Running Away: A Schoolmaster's Story is a short story by Dinah Craik that first appeared in volume 4 of Our Young Folks (December 1868).

bibl.title: In Bolton Woods
bibl.note: In Bolton Woods is a short story by Dinah Craik that first appeared in volume 7 of Our Young Folks (January 1871).

bibl.title: Lord Erlistoun
bibl.author: Dinah Mulock Craik
bibl.note:
Lord Erlistoun was a short story by Dinah Craik that was originally published in the the May 1857 issue of the National Magazine. It was later included in her book of short stories, Nothing New.
Sally Mitchell, Dinah Mulock Craik (Boston: Twayne Publishers, 1983), 133.

bibl.title: Three Companions
bibl.note: Three Companions was a poem by Dinah Craik.that first appeared in volume 6 of Our Young Folks (January 1870).

bibl.title: Domestic Tales
bibl.note: Domestic Tales is a short story compilation by Dinah Craik.

bibl.title: Plain Speaking
bibl.note: Plain Speaking was Dinah's book of essays.

bibl.title: The General Musical Advertizer & reviewer
bibl.note: This is a fictitious periodical that Dinah imagines Minna Lovell will write to Ben in the Crimea detailing all of the concerts he is missign in London.

bibl.title: In Memoriam
bibl.note: Tennyson's poem mourns the early loss of his friend Arthur Henry Hallam. The poem was immensely popular throughout the Victorian period.

bibl.title: The Author of John Halifax, Gentleman, a Memoir
bibl.note:
The Author of John Halifax, Gentleman was a memoir of Dinah Craik written by Louisa Parr. It was originally a section of Women Novelists of Queen Victoria's Reign (1897), also published by Hurst & Blackett.
Sally Mitchell, "Selected Bibliography," Dinah Mulock Craik (Boston: Twayne Publishers, 1983), 138.

bibl.title: Mary Barton: a Tale of Manchester Life
bibl.note: Mary Barton is a "condition of England novel" that centres around the working classes of Manchester.

bibl.title: A Tale of Two Cities
bibl.note: A Tale of Two Cities is a social problem novel by Charles Dickens serialized in 1859. The two cities referenced in the title are London and Paris before and during the French Revolution.

bibl.title: Elijah
bibl.note:
Elijah is an oratorio written by the acclaimed German-Jewish composer Felix Mendelssohn. The initial plans for the song were drafted with another composer named Karl Klingemann.
Howard E. Smither, A History of the Oratorio: The Oratorio in the Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries vol. 4 (Chapel Hill: U North Carolina P, 2000) Web.

bibl.title: Rolf's Leap
bibl.note: Rolf's Leap is a story about a dog written for "Our Young Folks" by Craik's cousin Georgiana Craik.

bibl.title: Tom Brown
bibl.author: Thomas Hughes
bibl.note: Tom Brown's School Days was a children's novel by Thomas Hughes. It follows the life of a young boy in an 1830s Rugby school.

bibl.title: Enoch Arden
bibl.author: Tennyson
bibl.note: A narrative poem by Lord Alfred Tennyson.

bibl.title: Household Gods
bibl.note: A play

bibl.title: Aurora Leigh
bibl.note: Aurora Leigh is an epic poem telling the story of a young woman writer by Elizabeth Barrett Browning

title.foreign: L'Histoire de France depuis les temps les plus reculés jusqu'en 1789 – racontée à mes petits enfants

bibl.title: Douglas
bibl.note:
“Douglas” was the title of a ballad published in Dinah’s 1875 musical collection, Songs of our Youth.
"Music," The Athenæum, no. 2471 (March 6, 1875): 333. accessed August 11, 2015.

bibl.title: Bertha's Love
bibl.note: Bertha's Love was published anonymously in volume 48 of Fraser's Magazine. In letter PU50 in the Princeton Parrish collection, Dinah reveals that the story was authored by her friend Miss James.

bibl.title: The Tragedy of Richard II
bibl.note: Richard II is a history play by William Shakespeare. It is based on King Richard II of Englands's life from the time of his coronation to his deposition (1377-1399).

bibl.title: Vanity Fair
bibl.note:
Vanity Fair was serialized in 20 parts in Punch Magazine from 1847 to 1848. It was later published in volume form by Bradbury and Evans in 1848.
Sutherland, John ed., Introduction to Vanity Fair, (Toronto: Oxford UP, 2008), vii-xxx.

bibl.title: Don Quixote
bibl.note: Don Quixote is an early Spanish novel (1605) written by Miguel de Cervantes.

bibl.title: Two Women
bibl.note: Two Women was a novel written by Dinah's cousin, Georgiana Craik, published in 1880. It appears to have been originally titled A Story of Two Women

bibl.title: Priscilla's Lot
bibl.note:
Priscilla's Lot was a three-chapter short story written by Dinah's cousin, Georgiana Craik. It was published in Bradbury and Evans's Once a Week and also appeared in Ticknor and Fields's Every Saturday.
Georgiana M. Craik, "Priscilla's Lot, Chapter III" Once a Week 3 (1867), 537–540.
Georgiana M. Craik, "Priscilla's Lot, Chapter III" Every Saturday 3 (1867), 714–716.

bibl.title: Poems Before Congress
bibl.note:
Barrett-Browning's Poems Before Congress was a collection of controversial political poetry. It received an overwhelmingly negative response following its English publication in 1860, and was frequently decried as "anti-English."
Katherine Montwieler, "Domestic Politics: Gender, Protest, and Elizabeth Barrett Browning's Poems before Congress," Tulsa Studies in Women's Literature 24.2 (2005): 291-317.

bibl.title: John Inglesant
bibl.author: Henry Shorthouse
bibl.note:
John Inglesant was initially self-published with 100 copies, and was re-published by Macmillan the following year.
ODNB.

bibl.title: Sunday Magazine
bibl.note: Sunday Magazine was an Evangelical journal designed to be read on the Sabbath. It was designed to be a compliment to Good Words, which Dinah often published in.

bibl.title: Ned Locksley, the Etonian; Or, the Only Son
bibl.note: Ned Locksley was a novel by Richard Seymour C. Chermside. Dinah helped to edit this novel for publication by Macmillan.

The Life of William Blake was a popular biography of the Romantic poet, William Blake, written by Alexander Gilchrist. It was published in 1863 after Gilchrist's death.
ODNB.

bibl.title: Captain Herbert
bibl.note: Captain Herbert was a 3-volume novel by George Cupples. Dinah reviewed this novel for Macmillan & Co around 1860 but it was published by Chapman and Hall in 1864.

bibl.title: The Moor Cottage
bibl.author: May Beverley
bibl.note: The Moor Cottage was an 1861 novel by May Beverley. Dinah read and edited this novel as a publisher's reader for Macmillan & Co. and praised its description of life in Crimea.

bibl.title: Harold
bibl.note: This appears to be an unpublished work, as Dinah said this was not suitable to be published by Macmillan.

bibl.title: Coach & Four
bibl.note: This appears to be an unpublished work, as Dinah said this was not suitable to be published by Macmillan.

bibl.title: Kyloe-Jock and the Weird of Wanton Walls
Out of the Depths: The Story of a Woman's Life
bibl.author: H.G. Jebb
bibl.note: Out of the Depths was originally published anonymously.

bibl.title: River Pontimac
bibl.note: River Pontimac was recommended to Dinah by Mrs. Hooper. Dinah did not read it.

div.bibl: Chattertonis possibly an unpublished poetry manuscript.

bibl.title: Agnes
bibl.note: Agnes was a domestic realist novel by the popular novelist, Margaret Oliphant. The novel is set in Italy and follows the life of Agnes Stanfield—a blacksmith's daughter who marries above her station.
In 1845, Dinah read and published a tale called "Sophia of Wolfenbuttel" from Luigi Bramieri's Nouvelle Morali di Francesco Soave

bibl.title: Felsina Pittrice: Lives of Bolognese Painters
bibl.note: Felsine Pittrice was a collection of stories about Bolognese painters, mostly from the seventeenth century. Dinah read and translated a tale from this collection in the early 1840s. Dinah's translation of Elisabetta Sirani was published in Chambers' Journal in July 1847.

bibl.title: Stratagems: A Story for Young People
bibl.note: Stratagems was a children's book by Dinah's good friend Camilla Dufour Crosland.

bibl.title: Bonnie Dundee
bibl.note: Bonnie Dundee is a traditional Scottish folk song. A version of it was popularized as a poem and song by Walter Scott in 1825.

bibl.title: Cam Ye By Atholl
bibl.note: Cam Ye By Atholl is a traditional Scottish folk song.

bibl.title: Consolation
bibl.note: "Consolation" was a piece of writing by a friend of Dinah's friend Miss Leslie. Dinah attempted to get it published by Chambers on her behalf around 1850.

bibl.title: My First and Last Novel
bibl.note: My First and Last Novel was an anonymous work by a member of the Household Words staff which Dinah recommended to Blackwood.

bibl.title: The Finding of the Saviour in the Temple
bibl.author: William Holman Hunt
bibl.note:
The Finding of the Saviour in the Temple is a famous painting by William Holman Hunt. It was one of the first attempts at a realistic, ethnographically and archaeologically accurate depiction of “The Finding in the Temple”/"Christ in the Temple" from the Gospel of Luke.
Frederic George Stephens, William Holman Hunt and His Works: A Memoir of the Artist’s Life with Descriptions of His Pictures (London: James Nisbet & Co, 1861), accessed 5 June 2017.
George P. Landow, “The Finding of the Saviour in the Temple,” Replete with Meaning: William Holman Hunt and Typological Symbolism (New Haven: Yale UP, 2009), Victorian Web, accessed 5 June 2017.

bibl.title: Views of the Architecture of the Heavens
bibl.author: John Pringle Nichol
bibl.note: Views of the Architecture of the Heavens was an influential book on nineteenth-century astronomy and cosmology by John Pringle Nichol—a Professor of Astronomy at the University of Glasgow.

bibl.title: Bahia
bibl.author: Benjamin Mulock
bibl.note: Bahia is an early photo of mid-nineteenth century Brazil taken and developed by Dinah's brother Benjamin Mulock. Ben took many photos of Bahia during his employment as a Photographer for the Bahia Railway line, and some of theses were published in periodicals such as the Illustrated London News. However, it seems that this particular photo originally went unpublished and was instead gifted to his friend Joe Mayall.

bibl.title: Fidelio
bibl.author: Ludwig von Beethoven
bibl.note:
Fidelio is Ludwig von Beethoven's only opera. It was performed in London beginning on 19 April 1860 at the Royal Italian Opera, Covent Garden (now the Royal Opera House).
"Royal Italian Opera," Musical World vol. 36 no. 16 (21 April 1860), 256.

bibl.title: Fidelio
bibl.author: Ludwig von Beethoven
bibl.note:
Fidelio was the first overture in the 1860 performance of Fidelio at the Royal Italian Opera in London. It preceded the first act and was played in E at an apparently "unprecedently [sic] rapid pace."
"Royal Italian Opera," Musical World vol. 36 no. 16 (21 April 1860), 256.

bibl.title: Leonore
bibl.author: Ludwig von Beethoven
bibl.note:
Leonore was the first overture in the 1860 performance of Fidelio at the Royal Italian Opera in London. It was played between the two acts and was played "magnificently" in C.
"Royal Italian Opera," Musical World vol. 36 no. 16 (21 April 1860), 256.

bibl.title: Little Dorrit
bibl.author: Charles Dickens
bibl.note: Little Dorrit is a satirical social problem novel by Charles Dickens. It was published in monthly shilling editions from December 1855 to June 1857.

bibl.title: The Mill on the Floss
bibl.author: George Eliot
bibl.note: The Mill on the Floss is a semi-autobiographical bildungsroman by George Eliot. It was published in three volumes by Blackwoods in 1860.

bibl.title: The History of Tom Jones, a Foundling
bibl.author: Henry Fielding
bibl.note: Tom Jones is an influential eighteenth-century picaresque novel/bildungsroman by Henry Fielding. It was published in four volumes and eighteen books in 1749.

div.bibl:
David Copperfield Charles Dickens
Bradbury & Evans London David Copperfield is the eighth novel by Charles Dickens. It is a bildungsroman about the titular character and is supposed to be Dickens's most autobiographical novel.
ODNB.

bibl.title: The Porter's Knot
bibl.author: John Oxenford
bibl.note:
The Porter's Knot was a serio-comic drama first performed in London in 1858. It was adapted from a French story by John Oxenford.
ODNB.
Henry Morley, "The Porter's Knot: Robson," Journal of a London Playgoer from 1851 to 1866 (London: George Routledge & Sons, 1866), 227 – 230.

bibl.title: The Compleat Angler
bibl.author: Izaak Walton
bibl.note:
The Compleat Angler was a best-selling seventeenth-century fishing manual written by Izaak Walton. It was reprinted almost as many times as The Pilgrim's Progress.
ODNB.

bibl.title: About Travelling and Travellers
bibl.author: Dinah Mulock Craik
bibl.note: About Travelling and Travellers was included in her book His Little Mother: And Other Tales and Sketches.

bibl.title: The Life and Letters of Sydney Dobell
bibl.author: Sydney Dobell

bibl.title: "with the sunshine & the sparrows & the flowers"
bibl.author: Sir Noel Paton

bibl.title: Middlemarch: A Study of Provincial Life
bibl.author: George Eliot
bibl.note: Middlemarch was serialized in volumes in 1871.

bibl.title: A Lord of the Creation
bibl.author: Marian James
bibl.note:
Marian James's A Lord of the Creation was first serialized anonymously in volume 51 of Littel's Living Age in 1856. It came out in volume form in August 1857.
"A Lord of the Creation," Littel's Living Age vol. 51 (Oct-Dec 1856): 19, 92, 153, 219.
"New Novels," Athenaeum no. 1557 (29 August 1857): 1097.
"Editor's Table," Ladies' Repository vol. 25 (1857): 238.

bibl.title: One Thousand and One Nights
The Arabian Nights' Entertainment
bibl.note: The famous collection of Middle Eastern and South Asian folklore known as One Thousand and One Nights was first translated into English in 1706. Its first English title was The Arabian Nights' Entertainment but it was (and is) colloquially referred to as Arabian Nights. The original Arabic text was compiled during the Islamic Golden Age, sometime between the eighth and thirteenth centuries.

bibl.title: Men of the Time: A Dictionary of Contemporaries
bibl.note: Men of the Time describes itself as "a dictionary of contemporaries, containing biographical notices of eminent characters of both sexes". Dinah had her own entry.

bibl.title: Chambers's Edinburgh Journal
bibl.note: Chamber's Edinburgh Journal was a magazine founded by William Chambers in 1832.

bibl.title: Macmillan's Magazine
bibl.note: Macmillan's Magazine was a monthly literary periodical published from 1859 to 1907 by Alexander Macmillan. Its first editor was David Masson.

bibl.title: The Athenaeum
bibl.note: The Athenaeum was a literary magazine published in London, England from 1828 to 1921.

bibl.title: The Sunday Library for Household Reading
A Legacy: Being the Life and Remains of John Martin, Schoolmaster and Poet
Holiday Afloat
bibl.note: Holiday Afloat was published in Good Words in 1884. It was illustrated by Margery May

bibl.title: The Little Grey Lady
bibl.note: The Little Grey Lady was a work that Dinah read as a publisher's reader for Macmillan & Co in 1860. It could potentially be an alternative title for the Moor Cottage (1861), because one of the characters is frequently referred to as a little grey lady.

bibl.title: A Defense of Mothers-in-Law
bibl.note: A Defense of Mothers-in-Law was published anonymously in Macmillan's Magazine of November 1860.
